International Alliance against State-Kidnapping and Hostage-Taking, initially known as '''Hostages' Alliance, is a global charity founded by collaborative endeavour of several former hostages and families of state-sponsored kidnap-victims.
The composition of the Directoral Committee includes its patron, Ana Diamond, Narges Mohammadi (recipient of 2023 Nobel Peace Prize), Eleanor Abbott, Mahia Farrokh, Sayyedeh Sema Jalili, SH. Vaghfi alongside a number of fellow senior experts, led by Dr Marika Ojala.
A core component of its mission is combating the rise of Hostage diplomacy or "State hostage-taking", a criminal practice which recently targets young women and girls worldwide for political and financial leverages. Its work encompasses three key areas: developing women-led strategies to prevent these human rights violations; as well as national and international legal frameworks to hold actors accountable, advocating for the release of captives; and delivering comprehensive assistance to victims and their families throughout crises and in their aftermath.
History
International Alliance against State Kidnapping and Hostage-Taking was officially launched in the constituent Balliol College of the University of Oxford in 2021.
The organization traces its origin to the Families Alliance Against State-Hostage Taking''' a notable collective initiative, driven by the efforts of few former hostages and families of detainees to campaign against governments that use individuals as bargaining chips. It formally launched at the United Nations General Assembly in New York on September 24, 2019.
Activities
The organization positions itself as a model for women-led crisis management NGOs, dedicated to enhancing the safety and mobility of girls and women worldwide while take up arms against kidnapping and unlawful detention on a global scale.
The HAlliance has been actively involved in addressing the ongoing detention of the British couple  Craig and Lindsay Foreman who were arrested in Iran in January 2025 on charges of espionage. and
in advocacy efforts following the kidnapping of 240 Israeli citizens by Hamas militants during the 7th October 2023 attacks. Its work centred in particular on the case of Emily Damari, a British national from London who was among the other civilians abducted that day.
